Congratulations! You have unlocked a new play activity: Balloon Tennis!
Gather materials such as balloons, paper plates, and paper straws. Take one paper plate and turn it over. 
Tape two straws to the back of the plate to make a sturdy racket. 
Repeat these steps to create more rackets for other players. Once your rackets are ready, blow up several balloons with your child for extra fun.
 Find an open area and start playing! Balloon Tennis is a fantastic way to keep kids active, improve their coordination, and most importantly, have fun together! Enjoy your game!

👋 Wave at your child and create silly shapes with your fingers - maybe a bunny, a bird, or whatever your imagination dreams up! 

👀 Watch as their curiosity grows, and invite them to try waving their shadow hand back.

Get ready to set up an exciting adventure right in your home! 🚩 

🔶 Using pillows, chairs, and blankets, create a fun and safe obstacle race for your toddler to explore. 

👋 The goal? For your little one to navigate the course by crawling, jumping, and climbing over, under, and through the obstacles.

💡 As they tackle each challenge, they’ll be developing important gross motor skills like coordination, balance, and strength. 

💛Not only will this activity get them moving, but it will also boost their confidence as they conquer each part of the race.

It’s an easy, playful way to promote physical development while having a great time together! Let the obstacle adventure begin! 🎉

Help your child to learn by sorting objects and things! 🔵🔷

By grouping items like a bear as an animal or a mango as a fruit, they’ll start to understand how different things fit together. 🧸

At home, find safe objects and let them sort them by colour, size, or type - plastic cups and plates are perfect for this! 
👀

Want to make it more interesting? Try sorting pots and pans by size: Can they fit the small pans into the larger ones? ☕

If you are outside, name different kinds of vehicles on the street or things you see in nature like stones, sticks, trees and flowers. 🌷

🔄 You can play the categorising game anywhere! Just look around and ask your child to find things from the category you say!

Sorting and grouping builds thinking skills, memory, and early logic -helping your child make sense of the world around them through playful discovery 🌈 

Adapted from Brain Building Through Play by Harvard University: https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/brainbuildingthroughplay/

Young children love to move - and songs with actions make it even more fun! Singing gives your child cues for how and when to move 🎵 

Sing songs to Your Child or a group of children in which they have to:
✅ Start and stop ❌
⬇️ Slow down and speed up ⬆️
Some song ideas:
- “If you’re happy and you know it”
- “Heads, shoulders, knees and toes”
- “Freeze dance” (play or sing music and freeze when it stops!)
- “Sleeping bunnies” (sleep, then hop!)
 
Movement songs build listening skills, self-control, and rhythm - while helping your child learn to follow instructions!

👀 Say what your child is doing while they are playing.

👂 This will help them learn the words to describe their actions.

😃 You can do it in a simple way, or in a silly way like a sports commentator, a news presenter, or a game show host.

💡 Ask questions like “What will you do next?” or “I see you want to put the ball in the jar. Is there another way to do that?”

This fun and interactive game helps your toddler learn about different parts of the body 🧸

📝 Start by drawing their body outline on a large piece of paper or with a stick on the ground. 

👂 As you go, ask them to point to and name different body parts. For example, you can say, “Where’s your nose?” or “Can you point to your feet?” 

👋As they point, encourage them to name each part. 

🎨 When you are done, you can colour in the outline or decorate it with anything you have in or around the house to make it more creative and engaging!

This fun and creative activity helps your child improve their body awareness, learn new words, and develop fine motor skills 💡

Turn your next trip to the store into a learning adventure! 🍞 

🍅 As you shop, pick a letter and talk about the items on your shopping list that start with that letter. 

👀 Ask your child to find other things in the shop that start with the same letter. 

This simple activity helps build your child’s letter recognition and vocabulary while keeping them engaged during the shopping trip ✨

It’s a fun, interactive way to learn about letters and sounds in real-world situations, turning an ordinary task into an exciting educational game! 🌈

Adapted from Sesame Workshop: https://sesameworkshop.org/resources/what-will-we-do/

👂 Play a game in which your child listens to and tries to remember strings of instructions.
This will be useful in school, at home, and later in life!

Start with just one instruction using an object in your home. For example “touch the red ball” 🔴

Slowly add more instructions (e.g “then pick up the cup "☕), but tell your child that they can only start once you’ve finished giving the instructions.
See how many your child can follow without forgetting!

🔄 Now swap roles! It’s your child’s turn to give you instructions! They can use the same objects if they want.
You can also try this game with a group of children! Make sure they take turns 😃

👀 I spy is a fun game to play with your child that will help them learn about letters and words!

Choose an object or a thing around you, and don’t tell your child what it is. It should be something that your child knows the word for. For example “ball” ⚽

👀 Then say “I spy with my little eye, something beginning with *and then say the first letter of the word* which in this case is “b”

Your child should look around and guess what the object is. When they guess it right, praise them and swap roles! If they can’t get it, give them some clues, like “it’s round” or “it’s black and white”. ✅

Play this game with as many objects as possible and as many different letters! Help your child to learn about the different letters and sounds in words. This will help them learn to read at home and school. 🎓

Playing games with letters can help your child learn the alphabet and how letters are put together to make words.

📝 Write a letter on a piece of card or paper (e.g. “p”)

👂 Say the letter out loud and ask your child to say it too!

Ask your child to say some words that begin with the letter “p”, give them clues like “What starts with “p”? Plant… What else? 🌱

👀 Ask your child to look for objects in your house that begin with a letter (eg “p” for plate). Help them find things.

🔄 Try a new letter every day!

Riddles and puzzles are a fun way to build thinking skills! 💡

Do you remember any riddles from your childhood? If you can’t then make one up, they can be very simple! 😃
Like “What can you see at night but not in the day” Answer: “The moon” 🌙

If your child is finding them difficult, try an easy one like: “What is round, bouncy and can be thrown or kicked?” Answer: “A ball” ⚽

Your child can also try making riddles! 💡

You can have fun with riddles anywhere at any time - like traveling on a bus, walking to school or in a car 🚗

🌱 Help your child learn by thinking and talking about vegetables! Here are 3 ideas for you:

🍅 Sorting vegetables
Mix together 2-3 different ingredients of your choice (like onions, tomatoes and corn example). Say: “Help me sort these vegetables into piles?” Try sorting them by size.

😃 Remind me!
Talk about your child’s experiences. Ask questions and wait for answers. Follow your child’s interests. 
“Can you help me remember what is at the market?” “Do they sell carrots at the market?” “Do they sell anything yellow at the market?” “What else do they sell?”

💡 Something similar
Say: We are going to think of some things that are similar or different from what I tell you. So listen carefully!”
Here is a tomato. Can you think of something else that is red like a tomato? 🍅
Can you think of something else that is round like a tomato? ⚽

These fun food games build memory, observation, and language - helping your child compare, recall, and explore the world through everyday things 🏆

Here are 3 fun animal-related games you can play! 

🧸 Active animals 
Take turns with Your Child doing animal actions: Hop like a frog, stretch like a cat, run like a dog, slither like a snake, flap like a bird.

💡 Groups of animals
What are all the animals we can think of that have feathers?
What are all the animals we can think of that eat plants? 🌱
What are all the animals we can think of that lay eggs?

😃 Counting rabbits
🔟 Find 10 rocks and tell your child that they are rabbits!
Put them in a line and ask them to count the rabbits.
Ask your child to give you 3 rabbits. Say “If you give me 3, how many rabbits do you have?”

These playful animal games build movement, counting, and thinking skills - while sparking your child’s curiosity about the natural world 🌈

Can you guess what it is?” 💚
 
These playful games build imagination, language, and thinking skills - while helping your child listen and express their own ideas in a fun way 💡

👂 Sit together in a cosy spot and begin a story the traditional way in your home language, like “Once upon a time...”

✨ Use your voice, hands, and expressions to bring the story to life. It could be about animals, a clever child, or a talking tree! Let your child add sounds or repeat words. You can even ask them what happens next!

💡 Traditional storytelling builds language, imagination, and cultural identity - and creates beautiful quiet time together.

Let’s bring wisdom to life through play! ✨ 

🌱 Think of a traditional proverb and act it out together. Pretend to be the animal or act out the scenario of the proverb - use movement, voices, and imagination!

📖 Here are some ideas to get you started:
- “Even an ant can hurt an elephant” - Pretend to be a big stomping elephant, then tiny ants that tickle its feet!
- “The lion doesn’t turn around when a small dog barks” - Be the calm, wise lion ignoring a noisy pup.
- “Wisdom is like a baobab tree - no one can embrace it alone” - Stand in a circle and stretch your arms to build a tree together.
- “A single bracelet does not jingle” - Clap or tap together and see how much louder it is with more hands!

👀Ask your child what they think the proverb means. 

This playful activity helps children explore big ideas like courage, kindness, and teamwork - through their bodies and imagination 💡

📝 Have fun being creative with writing!

You and Your Child can have fun writing with a pencil and paper, or with a stick and the sand!
If your child doesn’t know how to write letters, encourage them to draw shapes, and try to copy the shapes of letters. 🔵▶️

When they are more confident, encourage them to write letters and even words. 😃
Start showing them how to write their name and other important words for them, like mom, ball or milk.

Show them the simple things that you write - like shopping lists! Show them the words and each of the letters. Let them try to copy the words! 📖
 
🎉This playful writing time builds confidence, creativity, and early literacy - helping your child see that writing is useful and fun.

🏁 They can run, jump, crawl, walk on tiptoe, and any other way they want!

👀 The other players must copy what the leader does, and the leader can change movements at any time.

🔄 Take turns being the leader, and remember, you can play with just two people or as many as you want!

This game builds movement skills, attention and listening, and self-control, while having fun together! 👂

Create cards of the main six emotions with Your Child: happy, sad, angry, disgusted, surprised, afraid 😃😔😣

🔶 Draw, cut-out pictures from magazines, or take photos of family members showing different emotions. 

📝 Label each emotion and describe how each family member feels those emotions. 

🚩 Put the cards in a spot everyone agrees on, and use it throughout the day to name how everyone is feeling. For example, after school, everyone can point out the emotion they are experiencing. 

💡 Feel free to add new feelings as they come up. If someone doesn’t know what they are feeling, help them identify it by exploring how it feels in their body. Try together to find a new word for that emotion.

This can help everyone in the family become experts in understanding themselves and be aware of what their bodies need! 💛

Learning together is fun! 🎓

❓ Ask your child to think of a new, fun skill you could learn together. 
For example: keeping a ball in the air with your foot, juggling, making soup, moonwalking, whistling, saying the alphabet backwards, learning all the countries in Africa. 

🔄 Take turns trying out the new skill. Make sure to praise each other and learn and play together!

💛 Approach learning the skill in a kind and fun way, and do not judge your child or yourself for your ability in the skill. 

😃 Once you have mastered the skill, choose another skill to learn together.

🎵 Sit face-to-face with your child and try a fun clapping rhyme together. 

👋 Clap your hands, then each other’s, and repeat with a rhythm and song from your childhood – or make up a new one.

💚 Follow the words with a simple clapping pattern. You can swap in your own words or names to make it even more fun!

These clapping games have been popular among children from generation to generation, and help build rhythm, timing, memory, and laughter ✨

🔶 Stack three empty tins into a tower. 

🔵 One player throws a soft ball to knock them down while others run away. 

⏰ The “tin guard” collects and rebuilds the tower as quickly as possible while trying to tag the runners.

🔄 If you get tagged, you switch roles!

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Cleaning up is an important life skill. Get your teen to help you clean the house and make it fun!
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Make a list of all the chores in the house with your teen. For example: washing dishes, sweeping, cooking, making the beds, or doing laundry.
2. Every week, let each family member choose a chore they want to do. 
3. Agree when the chore should be done by.
4. Agree on what the consequence will be if it is not finished, and what small reward you can give as motivation to do the chore.
5. When the chore is done, praise your teen and let them mark it as 'done' on your list of chores. Praise and seeing progress are great motivation!
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* When your teen is part of the decision, your teen will be more willing to help out.
* A reward does not have to cost money and can be something small, like going to bed a bit later, having more time with friends, or doing a fun (free) activity together.
* If your teen did not complete the chore, do not discipline them harshly. Instead, ask them why they were not able to complete the task and give them the consequence you decided on earlier.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Playing Bao can be a fun way to spend time with your teen. They will be excited to play a game with you and not only do chores.
activities_teens_tz.resources_text::eng:
You can play by drawing a Bao board in the sand and finding 32 small seeds, stones, or other small objects.

The board has 2 rows with 8 small pits in each one, and 2 larger pits at the ends of the rows.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Place 2 pieces (seeds, stones or whatever you found) in each of the smaller pits. The larger pits at the end of each row should be empty.
2. Decide who will go first. Choose one pit from your side, pick up the stones (there should be 2) and move in a circle around the board, drop one stone into each pit. It is then the other person's turn. The goal is to get all your stones into your big pit before the other person.
3. Keep playing until you have no more stones or no one can move any stones anymore. The person with the most stones in the big pit wins.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* If you played before, tell your teen stories about you playing the game.
* Play a practice game to help your teen understand the rules.
* Celebrate your teen’s successes and encourage them to keep practising, even if they do not win right away.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Walking around your community is an easy and fun way to spend quality time together. It is good exercise and helps your teen learn about their community.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Plan: Discuss with your teen to choose a time and a place to walk together. It could be a nearby park, market, or any interesting area. If you were going there anyway, ask your teen if they want to come with you.
2. Observe and explore: Encourage your teen to ask questions about what they see on the walk. This could be about people, nature or buildings.
3. Learn together: Tell your teen things you know about the area. For example, who lives in different directions, your favourite flower, or what the area looked like long ago.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Use technology: Bring along your smartphone to take pictures of interesting things you see on the walk. Let your teen take photos and talk about it!
* Make it regular: Schedule regular walks and explore new locations to keep the activity fresh and fun.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Cooking traditional @global.regional food with your teen is a great way to connect, learn new skills, and share stories about your culture.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Choose a recipe: Find a traditional recipe that you and your teen would like to prepare. You can also ask friends and family for their favourites.
2. Gather ingredients: Ask your teen to help you get all the necessary ingredients and materials. 
3. Clean and prepare the cooking area: Make sure the kitchen area is clean and tidy before you start cooking. Teach your teen to wash their hands thoroughly when working with food.
4. Enjoy the meal: Eat the meal you prepared together! Talk about the flavours and textures of the food and share stories about traditional food in your culture.
5. Clean up: Once you have finished eating, clean up the cooking area together.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Plan with your teen: Ask your teen in the morning if they can help you with the cooking tonight. This gives them time to plan their school work and time with friends.
* Involve them: Tell them what you are cooking tonight and ask them if they know the ingredients. 
* Clear tasks: Ask your teen to chop the food or check the heat of the pots. They will be more interested if they help you and not only watch you cook.
* Make it regular: Ask them to help you with the cooking more and let them try different jobs like chopping different vegetables or starting a fire.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Gardening is a fun way to spend quality time with your teen. It is also very useful for them to learn how to grow food.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Choose some plants: Ask your teen to help you choose some plants to grow in the garden. This will make them feel involved.
You could choose plants you can eat, like vegetables or herbs, which you can grow and then cook together. 
2. Get creative with containers: You do not need lots of space to plant a garden. You can use old broken buckets, tin cans, or even plastic bottles as pots to plant in.
3. Plant the seeds: Make planting the seeds a fun activity. Have a "planting party" where you and your teen take turns planting the seeds in the soil. 
4. Water and care for the plants: Create a time table for watering and caring for the plants. Let your teen take charge of this task and ask them to look after the plants they planted.
5. Watch the plants grow: Encourage your teen to write down the changes they see every week to see how much the plants have grown.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Let your teen make some of the decisions, like where to dig the holes or which container to plant in. 
* Make gardening social by inviting friends or family to join the fun.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Charades is an easy, fun game that will teach your teen to think quickly, work together and be bold.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. One person thinks of a word, which they don’t tell anyone else.
2. They then have to act out the word, without speaking, to try and get the other people to guess the word.
3. Some words you could try to act out are things like sweeping, eating, playing a sport, or brushing teeth. 
4. If you guess the word right, it is the other person's turn.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Make sure everyone gets a turn to act out words or phrases.  
* Remember to praise your teen for trying. 
* If your teen is struggling to guess, give them hints on what it could be.
* If the game is too easy, try more difficult words. 
* Remember to have fun and support each other for the whole game.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng:
Role-playing is when you pretend to be someone in a certain situation, and act out how you think things will go. 

This is a fun way to help your teen understand how others might act or feel, and for you to learn more about how your teen thinks and feels.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Ask your teen if they want to try out this “role-playing” with you.
2. Ask your teen to choose a situation that they would like to act out. It can be something they saw at school, in your community, or on social media.  For example, being a teacher and student at their school.
3. Let your teen decide who should play which role, and act out the scenario together. 
4. Take time to talk about what you learned through role-playing. Ask questions like, "How did you feel acting out that role?" or, "What did you learn about that situation?". This will help your teen to think about how other people think and feel.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Take turns acting different roles. You can also swap roles to see how it changes the situation.
* Keep the activity fun. It doesn’t always have to be role play about something real. 
* Ask your teen to act as their favourite hero. Ask what they would do if they had super powers for a day.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng:
Hide and seek is a fun game that many people played when they were children. 

In this version of the game, you add a challenging twist for your teen.
activities_teens_tz.resources_text::eng: Pairs of any small objects you can find around the house (for example spoons, cups, bowls, empty boxes, shoes) Make sure you have two of each object.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Hide one of each object around the room. Make sure they are not too difficult to find, but also not too easy.
2. Show your teen the objects they need to find.
3. Let your teen look for the objects. When they find one, they must run back to you, name the object, and put it next to the matching object.
4. Repeat the process until all pairs of objects have been found.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Try to make the game more challenging by making the objects harder to find. 
* You can time how long it takes your teen to find all the objects and ask them to try and beat their time. 
* Choose objects with different shapes, sizes, and colours.
activities_teens_tz.extension_text::eng: Instead of a matching pair, show your teen an object that is “connected to” the object you hid in the room. For example, show your teen a sock, and they will search for something connected with that, like a shoe.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Mystery Box is a fun game in which you place an object inside a box, and let your teen ask questions to figure out what the object is.
activities_teens_tz.resources_text::eng:
You can use anything as a ‘box’ (a bucket, sack, packet), as long as your teen can not see what is inside.

You also need something to hide inside the mystery box.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Place any object inside the “Mystery Box”, without showing your teen.
2. Your teen now asks you questions to try and guess what it is. You can only answer with “Yes” or “No”.
3. When your teen is sure of the answer, they have to say, “I believe the mystery box is hiding …” and give their answer.
4. Swap roles with your teen and let them choose an object to hide in the box and you try to guess what it is.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* You can use different objects. You can also introduce themes, such as animals or fruits, to make the game more exciting. 
* You can allow your teen to choose the objects or themes. This makes them feel more involved and part of the game.
* Your teen can close their eyes and touch the mystery item to guess what it is.

6. Ask them how they remembered each one.
7. Now it is your turn. Let your teen be the master of the game – your teen chooses some items and tests your memory.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* You can time the activity to make it more exciting and competitive. 
* You can also ask your teen to come up with a story that involves all the items.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Cooking together is a wonderful opportunity to talk and connect, while also teaching your teen life skills.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Set a time and day that you and your teen are going to cook together. This will help both of you plan.
2. Teach them about what you are going to make together. Show them the ingredients and let them help measure how much you will be using today.
3. Give them a job to do, like fetching water, chopping, or stirring.
4. Enjoy the meal as a family and let your teen enjoy the pride of contributing to the family
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Involve them in the planning process by letting them choose the recipe or ingredients.
* Allow your teen to do as much as possible, including washing, measuring, cutting, and mixing.
* Encourage your teen to ask questions and to share what they are learning.
* Praise their efforts, even if the food does not turn out perfectly.
* Your teen will learn important life skills by cooking together: How to prepare food and plan well, appreciating the effort cooking takes, and how good it feels to contribute to family life.
* You might find that your teen has been wanting to help you cook but did not know how to ask.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Storytelling is a wonderful way to help your teen feel more connected with you, as well as with their family, history and culture.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Choose a time and place where you and your teen can talk comfortably. This could be after dinner, before bedtime, or during a walk outside.
2. Start by sharing your own story. It could be something that happened today, something you remember as a child or a memory that is special to you.
3. After you finish your story, ask your teen if they have any questions. If they don’t have any, ask them to share their own story with you.  
4. Listen to your teen's story, ask questions, and show interest in what they have to say.
5. If your teen is struggling to come up with a story, ask something like "What is your favourite childhood memory?" or "What is a tradition in our family that you enjoy?". They can even make up a story.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Create a safe space for your teen to share their stories. They will share more with you if they feel like you won’t be upset with them.
* Give your teen time to think and come up with their own story. This may not be easy for them to do.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Dancing is a fun way to get exercise, and a great way to learn about your teen’s interests.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Ask your teen what music they like. Show real interest by asking more questions like where they heard it and what they like about it.
2. Teach each other your favourite dance moves or learn new ones together. 
3. Once you have learned some new dance moves, practise them together. Remember to have fun.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Let your teen show you music and dance moves.
* Don't take it too seriously, be silly and have fun together.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng:
Setting weekly goals together teaches your teen how to set achievable tasks and work towards their larger long-term goals. 

This is a great way to bond and to support their personal growth and success in education.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. At the start of each week, sit down with your teen and ask them to choose one goal for that week. Make sure the goal is specific and can be done in one week. 
2. Share your own goal with your teen and try to support each other to reach your goals.
3. During the week, praise your teen for working on their goal. Celebrate their hard work.
4. If your teen does not reach their goal, use it as an opportunity to learn: Talk about why they did not reach it. What could they do better next time? Encourage them to re-plan their goal for next week.
5. Do this every week to start the habit of setting goals and completing them.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Let your teen choose their own goal.
* Make sure the goal is small enough for them to do in one week. Teens are more likely to set more goals if they complete their last goal. 
* Praise your teen for trying! They will put more effort in if they see that you care about their goal.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Helping your teen understand their strengths makes them feel confident in life and helps them take steps to grow in other areas as well.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Talk about your teen’s strengths. Ask them:
   * Which 3 things are you good at? (These can be small things, such as being on time for school, washing the dishes, or something they do with their friends.)
   * What helped you to be good at these things? (Make sure to talk about hard work and practice.)
2. Talk about your teen’s areas of improvement. Ask them:
   * What would you love to be better at? 
   * What can you do to reach that goal, and how can I help you? (Break down the big goal into smaller achievable goals/steps.)
3. Write down these smaller goals and encourage your teen to tick them off as they accomplish them.
4. Celebrate each achievement and encourage your teen to keep working towards their bigger goal.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Remember that teens will try more if they find things fun.
* Celebrate each step along the way and offer praise when your teen faces challenges.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng: Every house needs some cleaning and organising sometimes. Working with your teen to do this provides an opportunity for bonding and teamwork.
activities_teens_tz.steps_text::eng:
1. Identify a specific area in your home that needs cleaning and organising, such as a room, cupboard, or area on the floor.
2. Talk to your teen about what needs to be done to clean the space (Like sorting items into groups, or dusting a surface).
3. Give specific tasks to each person and work together to complete them. 
4. As you clean and organise, take the opportunity to talk and connect with your teen. Ask them about their interests and share stories from your own life.
5. When you are finished, take a moment to appreciate what you did and praise your teen for their part.
activities_teens_tz.tips_text::eng:
* Let your teen come up with an idea for what they think should be cleaned or organised.
* Take breaks and take your time. Remember to keep things fun. The goal is to spend time with your teen and teach them about being tidy and organised.

activities_teens_tz.intro_text::eng:
At the end of the day, take a minute to: 

* Talk to your teen about one fun thing they did. 
* Praise yourself for one thing you did well today. 
* You are a star!

* Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
* Ask each other, “What difficulty did you face today?”
* Ask each other, “How can I help you?”
* Try to do this together every day; it could be when you are eating dinner together or before you go to bed.

* You can’t always travel, but you can always dream! Ask your teen these questions:
* Where would you want to travel to? How long would you be away? What would you pack? What would you do on your trip? What would you see?
* Look at a map together or draw one.
* Choose a country that your teen has never heard of and learn more about the country.

You and your teenager can plan a guestlist of the famous people you’d most like to invite to your party. You can each have five people – they can be from the past or from the present time. Who would you invite? And would your guests get on well together?

* Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
* It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example: I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
* Say them to your teenager and ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
* Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
* Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

Tell your teenager something about when you were a teenager yourself. What things didn’t exist then? Phones with internet? What did you do for fun? What did you worry about? Don’t worry if they don’t tell you something in return – what’s important is that they listen and remember. Sometimes our teenagers forget that their parents are people too!

* Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
* Ask your teen, “If you had the superpower to […], how would you use it?”
* Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
* Now let your teen choose a superpower for you.
* Make sure you act out your superpower, too!

Have a conversation with your teen about something they like.

It can be about anything they choose to talk about: sports, friends, music, celebrities…

Try to listen to your teen and give them space to talk.

* Choose a storyteller to start making up a story.
* Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time.
* The storyteller needs to fit that word in their story.
* When the story is finished, try with a different storyteller!

* Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane.
* Say them to your teen and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
* Ask them why?
* Now think of three more situations or ask your teen to do it for you.

* Ask each other questions. They can be any questions about things you like or what you did today.
* The only rule is that you can’t answer “yes”, “no” or “maybe”.
* How long can you last? How creative can you get with your answers?
* Swap over and play again!

* First person says, “On Saturday, I am going to… (e.g., go to the park)”.
* Second person adds to first person, “On Saturday, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend).
* Each person adds to the previous, trying to think of all of the fun things to do on Saturday.

* Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
* Let your teen make up the next sentence.
* Then you make up a sentence.
* Take turns until you have a wonderful new story.
* Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
* Ask your teen what their favourite part of the story was!
